title: Verify environment and configure npm for project
description:
Pre-flight environment check and npm configuration. This must be done before scaffolding.

**Verify tooling:**
- Node.js is installed (currently v25.6.0 via Homebrew — this is fine)
- npm is installed (currently v11.8.0 — this is fine)
- TypeScript will be installed as a devDependency during scaffold, no global install needed

**Configure npm for this project:**
- The machine has Atlassian-specific npm configs in the user-level .npmrc (always-auth entries for Atlassian registries) that produce warnings and could interfere with installs
- Create a project-level .npmrc in the repo root with `registry=https://registry.npmjs.org/` to ensure this project always uses the public npm registry
- Verify `npm install` runs cleanly with no auth warnings from the project root

**Package manager choice:** npm (already installed, simple, no reason to add pnpm/yarn for a straightforward frontend project)

**Done when:**
- Running `node --version` shows v18+ (currently v25.6.0, well above minimum)
- Running `npm --version` shows v9+ (currently v11.8.0, fine)
- A project-level .npmrc exists pointing to the public registry
- `npm install` from the project root produces no Atlassian auth warnings

title: Mouse-tracking radial spotlight background effect
description: Add a radial gradient centered on the cursor that illuminates the dark navy background, like a flashlight beam. Use the teal accent color (rgba(100, 255, 218, 0.04)) as the inner color, updated on mousemove via a CSS background on the App wrapper. High visual impact with minimal DOM complexity.

title: Deploy site to S3 via Terraform
description:
Set up Terraform configuration to deploy the static site to AWS S3 for hosting at jamesmoessis.com.

**Infrastructure (all in one Terraform config):**
- S3 bucket configured for static website hosting
- Bucket policy for public read access
- CloudFront distribution (optional but recommended for HTTPS/caching)
- DNS configuration assuming jamesmoessis.com is accessible and can be pointed at the S3 bucket

**Deployment:**
- Build the Vite app (`npm run build`) to produce the `dist/` output
- Upload `dist/` contents to the S3 bucket via Terraform or a deploy script
- Configure proper content types and cache headers

**Terraform files to create:**
- `infra/main.tf` — provider config, S3 bucket, bucket policy, static site config
- `infra/variables.tf` — domain name, region, etc.
- `infra/outputs.tf` — bucket endpoint URL, CloudFront URL if applicable
- `infra/versions.tf` — required provider versions

**Assumptions:**
- The agent can assume jamesmoessis.com will be accessible to host via S3 static site
- AWS credentials will be available in the environment at apply time
- The site build is complete before deployment (this issue depends on all website work being finished)

**Acceptance criteria:**
- `terraform plan` shows correct resources
- `terraform apply` provisions the S3 bucket and hosting config
- Site is accessible at the S3 static site endpoint
- README or docs updated with deployment instructions

title: Scaffold Vite + React + TypeScript project
description:
Set up the project foundation:
- Initialize Vite + React + TypeScript project in the repo root
- Install and configure Tailwind CSS v4
- Define the dark color palette (navy background ~#0a192f, teal accent ~#64ffda, light slate body text, white headings)
- Set up base typography: Inter (sans-serif) for body, monospace for accents
- Create the base file structure: src/components/, src/data/, src/styles/
- Set up index.css with Tailwind directives and custom CSS properties for the color palette
- Create a minimal App.tsx shell that renders a full-page dark background
- Verify dev server runs and renders correctly

This is the foundation — all other tasks depend on this being complete.

title: Magnetic social links in sidebar
description: Add a subtle magnetic attraction effect to the sidebar social icons (GitHub, LinkedIn, email). When the cursor passes nearby, icons displace slightly toward it via CSS translate. Creates a playful, alive feeling without being distracting. Works best on the small isolated icon elements already in the sidebar.

title: Mouse-tracking teal shimmer on hero heading
description: Add a glowing teal shimmer/highlight that follows the horizontal mouse position across the hero heading ('James Moessis'). Implemented via a CSS background-clip: text gradient whose position is updated on mousemove. Creates a glossy light-reflection effect that feels native to the existing teal accent color theme.

title: Build Experience section
description:
Build the Experience section component (Experience.tsx):
- Section heading with numbered prefix: '02. Where I've Worked' (number in teal monospace, text in white)
- Tab-based layout (like Brittany Chiang's): vertical tab list on the left, content panel on the right
  - Each tab = a company/role
  - Clicking a tab shows that role's details in the content panel
  - Active tab highlighted with teal accent
- Content panel for each role shows:
  - Job title + company name (company name as teal link)
  - Date range
  - Bullet points describing responsibilities/achievements (teal arrow markers)
- Create a data file src/data/experience.ts with an array of experience entries, each having: company, title, url, dateRange, bullets[]
- Populate with 2-3 placeholder entries (TODO for user to fill with real data)
- Section id='experience' for anchor linking
- On mobile: tabs switch to horizontal scrollable or stacked layout

The data structure should make it easy for the user to add/edit their real experience later.

title: Build Projects section
description:
Build the Projects section component (Projects.tsx):
- Section heading with numbered prefix: '03. Some Things I've Built' (number in teal monospace, text in white)
- Featured project cards (2-4), each displayed as a large card/panel:
  - 'Featured Project' label in teal monospace above the title
  - Project title (white, clickable link)
  - Description box with a semi-transparent dark background
  - Tech stack tags listed below (e.g. 'Go', 'OpenTelemetry', 'Kubernetes')
  - Icon links: GitHub repo link, external link (if applicable)
  - Alternate layout: odd cards have content on the right, even cards on the left (like Brittany Chiang's staggered layout)
- Create a data file src/data/projects.ts with an array of project entries, each having: title, description, tech[], githubUrl?, externalUrl?, featured: boolean
- Populate with 2-3 placeholder entries (TODO for user to fill — suggested: atlassian-sampling-processor, OpenTelemetry Collector contributions)
- Section id='projects' for anchor linking

The data structure should make it easy for the user to add/edit projects later.

title: Polish: animations, responsive, meta tags
description:
Final polish pass across the entire site:

**Scroll animations:**
- Add subtle fade-in-up animations as each section enters the viewport
- Use Intersection Observer API (or Framer Motion if already installed)
- Stagger animations for list items (tech tags, experience bullets, project cards)
- Keep it minimal — no flashy effects, just gentle reveals

**Responsive design:**
- Verify all sections look good on mobile (320px), tablet (768px), and desktop (1200px+)
- Navbar hamburger menu works correctly on mobile
- Sidebars hidden on mobile
- Experience tabs switch to horizontal or stacked layout on small screens
- Project cards stack vertically on mobile
- Typography scales appropriately

**Meta tags and SEO:**
- Set page title: 'James Moessis — Software Engineer'
- Add meta description
- Add Open Graph tags (og:title, og:description, og:image placeholder)
- Add favicon (can be a simple placeholder)

**Final checks:**
- No console errors
- Smooth scrolling works for all nav links
- All placeholder TODOs are clearly marked for the user to find and replace
- Site looks polished and professional with just the placeholder content

Depends on all section tasks being complete.

title: Build Contact section and Footer
description:
Build the Contact section (Contact.tsx) and Footer (Footer.tsx):

**Contact section:**
- Section id='contact' for anchor linking
- Just three icon links centered horizontally: GitHub, LinkedIn, and Email (mailto:)
- Icons only — no heading text, no message, no CTA button
- Use inline SVG icons for GitHub and LinkedIn logos, and a mail/envelope icon for email
- Icons should be light slate color, turning teal on hover
- Generous spacing between icons
- Placeholder URLs (TODO for user to fill in their actual GitHub, LinkedIn, and email)

**Footer:**
- Simple centered footer at the bottom of the page
- Small muted text: 'Built by James Moessis' or similar (placeholder)
- Optional: link to GitHub repo of this site
- Minimal styling — should not draw attention away from the content above

title: Build About section
description:
Build the About section component (About.tsx):
- Section heading with numbered prefix: '01. About Me' (number in teal monospace, text in white)
- Horizontal rule or decorative line after the heading
- 2-3 paragraphs of bio text in slate color (placeholder — TODO for user to fill)
- Tech stack list: a grid or inline list of technologies (e.g. Go, Java, TypeScript, Kubernetes, OpenTelemetry, etc.) — use text labels or simple styled tags, no external icon dependencies needed
- Optional: placeholder for a profile photo on the right side (can be a gray box placeholder)
- Content width should be constrained (max-w-2xl or similar) for readability
- Section should have an id='about' for anchor linking from the navbar

Use placeholder content throughout — user will fill in real bio text and finalize tech list.

title: Build Hero section
description:
Build the Hero section component (Hero.tsx) — the first thing visitors see:
- Full viewport height section
- Small teal-colored greeting text in monospace (e.g. 'Hi, my name is')
- Large bold name heading (placeholder: 'James Moessis')
- Secondary heading in muted color (placeholder subtitle/tagline — TODO for user to fill)
- 1-2 sentence description paragraph in slate text (placeholder — TODO for user to fill)
- CTA button with teal accent border that smooth-scrolls to the Projects section
- Content should be left-aligned with generous left padding (matching Brittany Chiang's layout)
- Vertically centered in the viewport

Use placeholder text throughout — the user will fill in real content.

title: Build fixed Navbar with section links
description:
Build the top navigation bar component (Navbar.tsx):
- Fixed position at top of page
- Semi-transparent dark background with backdrop blur
- Links to each section: About, Experience, Projects, Contact (anchor links using #ids)
- Numbered section labels in monospace font (01. About, 02. Experience, etc.)
- Show/hide on scroll: hide when scrolling down, reveal when scrolling up
- Mobile: hamburger menu that opens a centered overlay with the same links
- Subtle transition animations for show/hide behavior
- Use the teal accent color for hover states

Depends on: scaffold (jamesmoessis-3sc) being complete with Tailwind and base styles set up.

title: Build fixed sidebars (social icons left, email right)
description:
Build the two fixed sidebars for desktop viewports (like Brittany Chiang's site):

**Left sidebar (SocialSidebar.tsx):**
- Fixed position on the left edge of the screen
- Vertical column of social icon links: GitHub, LinkedIn
- Icons in light slate, turning teal on hover
- Vertical line extending below the icons down to the bottom of the viewport
- Hidden on mobile/tablet (below ~768px)

**Right sidebar (EmailSidebar.tsx):**
- Fixed position on the right edge of the screen
- Email address written vertically (rotated 90 degrees, using CSS writing-mode)
- Placeholder email (TODO for user to fill)
- Light slate color, teal on hover, links to mailto:
- Vertical line extending below the text down to the bottom of the viewport
- Hidden on mobile/tablet

Both sidebars should use the same vertical line style and positioning logic. They appear after a subtle fade-in on page load.
